Renewable energy technologies face chall.title: Barriers to Renewable Energy Technologies - Union of Concerned Scientists
content: Barriers to Renewable Energy Technologies - Union of Concerned Scientists
Giving Tuesday 2X MATCH—donate now!
Climate change is one of the most devastating problems humanity has ever faced—and the clock is running out.
The energy choices we make today could make or break our ability to fight climate change.
Our transportation system is outdated and broken—and it needs to change.
The US food system should be providing healthy, sustainable food for everyone.
Why isn’t it?
They’re the most dangerous invention the world has ever seen.
Can we prevent them from being used again?
Democracy and science can be powerful partners for the public good—and both are under attack.
Published Jun 6, 2014 Updated Dec 20, 2017 In March 2017, wind and solar accounted for 10 percent of all US electricity generation for the first time ever.
Although 10 percent may not sound high, it reflected a major achievement for both technologies, which have overcome numerous barriers to become competitive with coal, natural gas, and nuclear power.
But renewables still face major obstacles.
Some are inherent with all new technologies;
others are the result of a skewed regulatory framework and marketplace.
This page explores the barriers to renewable energy in detail, with a focus on wind and solar.
For more on why renewable energy is so important, please see our page on the Benefits of Renewable Energy Use.

The most obvious and widely publicized barrier to renewable energy is cost—specifically, capital costs, or the upfront expense of building and installing solar and wind farms. Like most renewables, solar and wind are exceedingly cheap to operate—their “fuel” is free, and maintenance is minimal—so the bulk of the expense comes from building the technology.

The average cost in 2017 to install solar systems ranged from a little over $2,000 per kilowatt (kilowatts are a measure of power capacity) for large-scale systems to almost $3,700 for residential systems. A new natural gas plant might have costs around $1,000/kW.
Wind comes in around $1,200 to $1,700/kw.

Higher construction costs might make financial institutions more likely to perceive renewables as risky, lending money at higher rates and making it harder for utilities or developers to justify the investment.

For natural gas and other fossil fuel power plants, the cost of fuel may be passed onto the consumer, lowering the risk associated with the initial investment (though increasing the risk of erratic electric bills).

However, if costs over the lifespan of energy projects are taken into account, wind and utility-scale solar can be the least expensive energy generating sources, according to asset management company Lazard.
As of 2017, the cost (before tax credits that would further drop the costs) of wind power was $30-60 per megawatt-hour (a measure of energy), and large-scale solar cost $43-53/MWh.
For comparison: energy from the most efficient type of natural gas plants cost $42-78/MWh;
coal power cost at least $60/MWh.
Even more encouragingly, renewable energy capital costs have fallen dramatically since the early 2000s, and will likely continue to do so.
For example: between 2006 and 2016, the average value of photovoltaic modules themselves plummeted from $3.
50/watt $0.
72/watt—an 80 percent decrease in only 10 years.
Nuclear power, coal, and natural gas are all highly centralized sources of power, meaning they rely on relatively few high output power plants.
Wind and solar, on the other hand, offer a decentralized model, in which smaller generating stations, spread across a large area, work together to provide power.
Decentralization offers a few key advantages (including, importantly, grid resilience), but it also presents barriers: siting and transmission.
Siting is the need to locate things like wind turbines and solar farms on pieces of land.
Doing so requires negotiations, contracts, permits, and community relations, all of which can increase costs and delay or kill projects.
Transmission refers to the power lines and infrastructure needed to move electricity from where it’s generated to where it’s consumed.
Because wind and solar are relative newcomers, most of what exists today was built to serve large fossil fuel and nuclear power plants.

But wind and solar farms aren’t all sited near old nuclear or fossil fuel power plants (in fact, some areas with fewer older power plants, such as the Great Plains and Southwest, offer some of the country’s best renewable potential).
To adequately take advantage of these resources, new transmission infrastructure is needed—and transmission costs money, and needs to be sited.

Both the financing and the siting can be significant barriers for developers and customers, even when they’re eager for more renewables—though, again, clean energy momentum is making this calculation easier.
For most of the last century US electricity was dominated by certain major players, including coal, nuclear, and, most recently, natural gas.
Utilities across the country have invested heavily in these technologies, which are very mature and well understood, and which hold enormous market power.
This situation—the well-established nature of existing technologies—presents a formidable barrier for renewable energy.
Solar, wind, and other renewable resources need to compete with wealthier industries that benefit from existing infrastructure, expertise, and policy.
It’s a difficult market to enter.
New energy technologies—startups—face even larger barriers.
They compete with major market players like coal and gas, and with proven, low-cost solar and wind technologies.
To prove their worth, they must demonstrate scale: most investors want large quantities of energy, ideally at times when wind and solar aren’t available.
That’s difficult to accomplish, and a major reason why new technologies suffer high rates of failure.
Increased government investment in clean energy—in the form of subsidies, loan assistance, and research and development—would help.
You don’t tend to see multi-billion dollar industries without also seeing outsized political influence—and the fossil fuel industry is no exception.
Oil Change International estimates that the United States spends $37.
5 billion on subsidies for fossil fuels every year.
Through direct subsidies, tax breaks, and other incentives and loopholes, US taxpayers help fund the industry’s research and development, mining, drilling, and electricity generation.

While subsidies have likely increased domestic production, they’ve also diverted capital from more productive activities (such as energy efficiency) and constrained the growth of renewable energy (solar and wind enjoy fewer subsidies and, generally, receive much less preferential political treatment).

For decades, the fossil fuel industry has used its influence to spread false or misleading information about climate change—a strong motivation for choosing low-carbon energy sources like wind or solar (in addition to the economic reasons).
Industry leaders knew about the risks of global warming as early as the 1970s, but recognized that dealing with global warming meant using fewer fossil fuels.
They went on to finance—and continue to fund—climate disinformation campaigns, aimed at sewing doubt about climate change and renewable energy.
Their efforts were successful.
Despite widespread scientific consensus, climate action is now a partisan issue in the US congress, complicating efforts to move from fossil fuels to clean energy.

The disconnect between science and policy means that the price we pay for coal and gas isn’t representative of the true cost of fossil fuels (ie, it doesn’t reflect the enormous costs of global warming and other externalities).

This in turn means that renewables aren’t entering an equal playing field: they’re competing with industries that we subsidize both directly (via government incentives) and indirectly (by not punishing polluters).
Emission fees or caps on total pollution, potentially with tradable emission permits, are examples of ways we could use to help remove this barrier.

Renewable energy opponents love to highlight the variability of the sun and wind as a way of bolstering support for coal, gas, and nuclear plants, which can more easily operate on-demand or provide “baseload” (continuous) power.
The argument is used to undermine large investments in renewable energy, presenting a rhetorical barrier to higher rates of wind and solar adoption.
But reality is much more favorable for clean energy.
Solar and wind are highly predictable, and when spread across a large enough geographic area—and paired with complementary generation sources—become highly reliable.
Modern grid technologies like advanced batteries, real-time pricing, and smart appliances can also help solar and wind be essential elements of a well-performing grid.

Tests performed in California, which has some of the highest rates of renewable electricity use in the world, provide real-world validation for the idea that solar and wind can actually enhance grid reliability.

A 2017 Department of Energy report confirmed this, citing real-world experience and multiple scientific studies to confirm that the United States can safely and reliably operate the electric grid with high levels of renewables.
Many utilities, though, still don’t consider the full value of wind, solar, and other renewable sources.
Energy planners often consider narrow cost parameters, and miss the big-picture, long-term opportunities that renewables offer.
Increased awareness—and a willingness to move beyond the reliability myth—is sorely needed.

Renewable energy technologies face chall.title: Tackling grand challenges in wind energy through a socio-technical ...
content: Tackling grand challenges in wind energy through a socio-technical ...
Thank you for visiting nature.
com.
You are using a browser version with limited support for CSS.
To obtain the best experience, we recommend you use a more up to date browser (or turn off compatibility mode in Internet Explorer).
In the meantime, to ensure continued support, we are displaying the site without styles and JavaScript.
Advertisement Nature Energy volume 8, pages 655–664 (2023)Cite this article 1831 Accesses 3 Citations 65 Altmetric Metrics details Wind power has an important role to play in tackling climate change.
Key challenges in wind energy science and innovation must be overcome to increase the penetration and capability of this technology.
However, the success of these efforts heavily depends on how society engages with the development of wind power infrastructure.
Consequently, grand challenges exist in both technical and social domains, yet little research has made substantial efforts in connecting them.
Here we review the social science and humanities literature on wind energy to illustrate the social dimensions of previously identified technical challenges.

We suggest that a socio-technical lens enables an interdisciplinary approach to overcome the prevalent tendency of silo thinking in wind energy research and use it to explore socio-technical grand challenges related to the design, planning, development, operational and end-of-life phases of wind energy.

Finally, we provide an outlook for research, practice and innovation, including an interdisciplinary and socio-technical research agenda for wind energy science, renewable energy developments and science policy in general.
You have full access to this article via your institution.
Complex societal problems within the past decade increasingly have been framed as ‘grand challenges’ in science, technology and innovation (STI) policy with a discourse of its own1,2,3.
Among the most well known of these grand challenges are climate change and energy security1.
In the European Union’s STI policy, these grand challenges have, for example, been framed as a matter of ensuring secure, clean and efficient energy and undertaking action on climate change4.

We argue that tackling the grand challenge of climate change requires integration of perspectives across disciplines to address its ‘wicked’ nature5,6 that cuts across multiple entangled domains and issues.
Our ability to solve the climate challenge relies on the deployment of a large quantity of renewable energy infrastructure;
however, development and deployment of renewables is all too often sought in isolation by individual disciplines, frequently from the technical sciences.
Furthermore, decision-makers and investors frequently use a technical go-to solution, which ends up with discipline-oriented grand challenges to enhance and accelerate renewable energy deployment.

We argue that there is a need to enhance our understanding of how the deployment of renewables bears with it social dynamics (and potential contestations), which must be addressed alongside the technical challenges if we want to meet the overarching climate challenge.

Here we use the case of wind power—the most mature of existing renewable energy technologies, potentially providing 30–50% of the future electricity supply in many countries7—to explore a pathway and a means to develop an interdisciplinary and essentially socio-technical perspective to approach the grand challenge of climate change.

The literature on wind energy and on renewable energy transitions, generally, is predominantly split between the technical and natural sciences on the one hand and social sciences and humanities (SSH) on the other hand.

Studies that combine both perspectives are rare, and both bodies of literature have tended to focus on particular phases of the wind energy life cycle of design, planning, development, operation and end of life, while rarely looking across all the stages.

The technical sciences often consider social issues as separate ‘barriers’ to wind power deployment, treating these as somewhat removed from issues related to the technological design and operation of wind turbines.

Solutions to overcome these barriers have often been framed within a techno-economic rationale (for example, of incentives, costs and benefits) and treating non-experts (‘lay people’) as passive or hampering desired progress.
But SSH is often guilty of overlooking how the design and operation of technologies shape public responses to renewables and of often disregarding the technical aspects of these developments.
Such monodisciplinary perspectives risk ignoring how technologies are always also social, co-producing the agency of different actors.
A recent series of articles8,9,10,11 has extended the grand challenges discourse into the wind energy realm.
While this was initiated by engineering science, SSH and environmental sciences have since been encouraged to extend these insights by highlighting ‘social grand challenges’11.
This indicates a potential for cross-fertilization between perspectives.
Such collaboration is sorely needed as local opposition to renewable energy deployments has been growing in the past decade12,13, which risks jeopardizing our ability to meet climate ambitions.

While other SSH scholars have already advocated that technical researchers should give social issues greater attention14,15, there is great potential for influence by SSH directly participating in the grand challenges agenda.
In this sense, we advocate for an interdisciplinary full life-cycle approach to wind energy.
This is of utmost importance as wind energy technologies on their own do not matter much if they cannot be deployed in and with society.

To support this goal, we start with a critical review of the existing literature on wind energy, where three technical grand challenges have gained prominence, and we illustrate how these are imbued with issues just as relevant for SSH.

Showing what SSH can bring to our understanding of wind energy, we then propose an interdisciplinary lens that can look holistically at all phases of wind energy—design, planning, development, operation and end of life—and thereby better support climate change mitigation.
Through this socio-technical lens, we identify a series of key research gaps—or what could be coined as socio-technical grand challenges—along the full life cycle.
On the basis of this, we outline a future research agenda that holds promise to better tackle the grand challenge of climate change.
Our aim is, therefore, to move the state of the art in wind energy science forward by illustrating the socio-technical dimensions of wind energy along its full life cycle.

In the following, we use the grand challenges carved out in the technical literature as a scheme to shed light on how these challenges related to space, scale and system are not just technical or economic but are entangled with social dimensions that are ripe for interdisciplinary enquiry.
In the techno-economic literature, spatial conditions are considered a grand challenge8,9,16.

The energy in the wind does, indeed, depend on the geographical location, as particular conditions of the airflow are shaped by terrain, be it mountains, flat plains, vegetation or other spatial conditions.

Considerable research goes into detailed prediction and characterization of wind resource conditions, examining flows at varying levels17,18,19, to find the optimal siting of wind turbines that ensures the highest possible energy production20,21.

Considering the social (or ‘human’) dimension of spatial conditions for the deployment of wind farms, we find that different location and territorial challenges emerge that further constrain the siting of wind turbines.
These are not per se determined by the characteristics of wind resources.

Acknowledging the interrelationship between wind energy resources and socio-spatial conditions, analysis should take into account how wind energy development not only takes place in space but also has specific relations to a place and its history22,23 and may evoke particular perceptions and emotions24,25.
The erection of wind turbines onshore or offshore can place new values on land and sea and render particular areas controversial26.
This means that different land uses and marine interests can result in contestations, while the deployment of wind turbines has socio-spatial consequences that have often been the cause of conflicts.

First, land has become an increasingly scarce resource (‘asset’)26, co-constituted by regulatory or clandestine processes of identifying, designating or establishing suitable locations for wind turbines.
Land thus increasingly constitutes a critical resource for the commodification and marketization of wind energy26,27,28,29.

While regulatory processes of assigning suitable or acceptable sites can be ambiguous29,30,31, the underlying practices and implications of land acquisition for wind turbines has had a pervasive impact on local populations.
Most notably, it recently has been affiliated with issues of land grabbing32,33, colonization by wind energy34,35,36, dispossession37,38 and rentiership39,40, especially in the Global South.
This research strand emphatically hints at the importance of energy justice in an intensified search for wind farm sites.
Second, the deployment of wind turbines has various implications for the affected areas, such as site-specific socio-economic or environmental impacts and benefits.

These impacts materialize in the uneven distribution of wind energy landscapes22,23,41,42, for example, areas with good wind energy profiles often tend to occur in sparsely populated areas or wind energy developments take place in disadvantaged areas, thus spurring further de-population27, marginalization or, conversely, prosperity, while often ignoring the relationships that people have with these landscapes and places43,44,45.

Scrutinizing the human dimension of wind energy deployment, there has been prolific research within social acceptance of wind energy46 that examines the manifold relationships between wind turbines as technical infrastructures, spatial conditions and people’s responses.

Hence, local resistance to wind farm developments (which still tends to be simplified as NIMBY (not in my backyard) behaviour by many decisionmakers and developers) has been rethought as responses to disruptions to place identity47,48, place attachment49,50 and spatial–visual perceptions51.

Likewise, issues of spatial justice are embedded in wind energy politics52,53,54 and in people’s responses to wind farms55,56, all pointing at the importance of social values and meanings attached to physical material conditions for wind energy developments, that is, their socio-technical configuration.
Another technical challenge receiving interest in the techno-economic literature is the continuous upscaling of wind turbine technology, where the industry sector seeks ever-larger turbines8,10.

This continuous effort to drive down the cost of each kilowatt hour produced57,58 by increasing the energy yield per turbine59,60 has resulted in an overwhelming focus on reducing the levelized cost of energy—a research focus that today seems somewhat paradoxical or outdated as onshore wind energy has become cost competitive against fossil fuels.
Science here is particularly challenged by aerodynamics, structural dynamics and—when offshore—hydrodynamics.
Making wind turbines larger has been part of the engineering ethos since the birth of the wind energy sector in the 1970s.

When turbine sizes were around 250 kW in the 1980s, their contribution to the power system was considered marginal, but by the end of the 2010s, the industry could boast onshore turbines of up to 4 MW and around 8 MW for offshore61, reflecting a 30-fold increase in capacity.
Today, the socio-technical imaginary of wind energy holds the potential of developing 20 MW wind turbines within a few years and the experimentation with turbine structures up to 450 m tall.

The marketization of wind power has been supported by the shifting regulatory context of financial instruments61,62 (for example, national and European Union-based support schemes and funding of research and development, planning regulations), transforming wind into a commodity worthy of investment24,63,64, over time construing wind power as critical infrastructure28,61,62.

Large wind turbine designs currently dominate the market, leaving little space for developing designs in a wider range of directions, for instance, towards urban wind or other small-scale designs that are more affordable for non-commercial actors.

The scalability of turbine structures has, however, not gone unnoticed by societal actors such as local communities, who express an increasing anxiety about the visibility and dominance of wind turbines in landscapes and their everyday lives51,65.

Opposition has often centred around the size of wind turbines and how they have outgrown the human scale, creating a fundamental mismatch between wind energy infrastructure and the scale of local landscapes.
Others also raise concerns over how ever-larger wind turbines have marginalized small investors due to the increased capital cost of wind energy projects61,62,66.
In Denmark, for instance, a paradigm shift has taken place in the wind energy sector61 as small-scale cooperative investors have been gradually ostracized.

Small-scale investors have become increasingly unable to invest61 due to the effect of entangled processes of technological development (upscaling), shifting support and financing instruments and ownership models, further spurred on by the European Union’s requirement for wind power to be subject to public tenders.
Here bidders compete by building the largest wind farm at the lowest cost (in terms of subsidy from the state), which favours large utility-scale wind farm developments.

Today, the roots of Denmark’s wind energy sector—the local cooperatives—have been eradicated without facilitating public debate around it, spurring increased local opposition to wind power over the past decade61.

Upscaling of wind power through marketization raises issues of distribution, recognition and procedural justice67 of the energy transition and leads to challenges in engaging societal actors to utility-scale wind power.

An SSH lens can help to shed critical light on the underlying techno-economic and techno-scientific valuations of ‘what matters’ in the design of wind energy technologies, their socio-material effects and their inherent politics for the agency of different actors around wind power developments, while being reflexive of the role of situated histories of wind power developments in particular sites.
Finally, the techno-economic literature is concerned with the optimal and safe integration of wind energy into the future electricity grid9,68,69.
This is seen as a precondition for the further deployment and expansion of wind energy and other intermittent renewable sources, with one of the solutions being to make it ‘smarter’.

The smart grid employs a digital layer on the energy system to manage an increasingly decentralized system based on fluctuating electricity production from renewable energy sources, particularly wind power.
Smart grids hold the promise of a broader decarbonization of our electricity system, through optimized system integration, flexibility and demand management70.

Furthermore, smart grids enable cross-sector coupling with other energy technologies and fuels, such as power-to-X technologies (that is, conversion technologies transforming renewable energy into, for example, hydrogen) and aggregation into energy islands.
Proponents of the smart-grid concept expect consumers to play a key role by shifting their electricity consumption during the day, motivated by dynamic pricing in the energy market70,71.

The required end-user flexibility72,73 is achieved by doing daily chores (for example, laundry, dishwashing) when ‘the wind blows’ and outside peak demand hours or by allowing energy companies to control, for example, residents’ heat pumps or electric car chargers74.
The social sciences are often delegated the task of investigating how consumers of wind energy can be persuaded (or nudged) to take on this role74.

We argue that an approach that can move beyond the nudging of consumers through pricing would be helpful, to facilitate a better understanding of, for example, the role of visions, user images and everyday life and the design of socio-technical systems74,75,76.

Visions represented in white papers, policy briefs and so on are important to explore because they actively ‘create the future’ by mobilizing and aligning actors into pursuing certain futures instead of others, such as a future with wind as critical infrastructure in the envisioned smart energy grid75,77.

Moreover, the image of the consumer as a tech-savvy and economically rational agent (the Resource Man)78, which configures the consumer as a “Mini-Me” version of his utility provider79, excludes a multiplicity of other rationalities and future users in the designs74,79.
It naturalizes and reinforces certain policies and development paths over others, for instance, more techno-economic and marketable and less citizen-driven sustainable transition paths80.

Such paths based on a particular configuration of smart energy may risk producing colliding valuations of ‘what matters’, such as between economic valuations and more social valuations of community concerns and energy justice63.
Other SSH studies have looked at what happens when visions of the smart grid come together with users of wind energy at the household level.

A recent review of the SSH literature on flexibility and demand-side management81 points to challenges related to the capacities of the users to actually change the timing and quantity of energy consumed, their sense of control and agency, and their own stake in managing the electricity grid.

The taken-for-granted ease with which these systems are taken up as intended is challenged in many studies70,74,82,83,84 and may even spur family conflicts70,74,83,84, for instance, when parents spy on their children via energy management systems74.

Single measures such as price incentives alone to make people ‘play along’ will not succeed in the complex reality of everyday life85 and may cause unexpected responses, for example, user hacks into the systems to improve them74,86, while also producing justice issues, for example, related to gender (as women are still often left with the majority of domestic work but might also be less inclined to use smart technologies)72,82.

Further social inequalities and justice issues are related to the uneven distribution of who is able to be flexible and adjust electricity consumption (related to socio-economic status, non-flexible working hours, strict rules for use of washing machines and the like in rental or other collective housing and so on).

In countries such as Denmark that rely mostly on intermittent resources such as wind power, these issues are critical and call for careful consideration of how flexible electricity markets are constructed and whose expertise should be included in their design.
System integration of wind energy thus requires simultaneous changes in technology, markets, regulations and politics75.

The growing role of prosumers (that is, consumers that produce electricity from their own sources87) and the European Union’s recent call to give citizens a stronger role in the energy transition by forming renewable energy communities88,89 result in radically different roles and responsibilities that need to be negotiated.

This needs attention as emergent business models such as aggregators and virtual power plants often rely on wind energy as the critical energy resource90,91 but also highlight inequalities in the resources available to citizens, leaving some unable to invest or participate in an energy community72,92.
Such tensions between neoliberal and communitarian logics93 have become even more pertinent with rising electricity prices and the unfolding energy crisis since the beginning of 2022.

Having shown above how SSH has made important contributions to the framing of notionally technical problems, we now move the research agenda forward with our proposal for a socio-technical lens on what we term the life-cycle approach.
Through it, we shed light on central research questions and gaps.
Founded in science and technology studies (STS)94,95,96, a socio-technical lens helps to enquire into how ‘the social’ and ‘technologies and scientific knowledges’ are co-produced97,98.

Originating from studying scientists and engineers in their laboratories, the STS literature has explored how scientific facts are socio-materially produced, that is, by both human and non-human actors.
From there, STS has ventured into technological innovation, the making of economies and markets, and recently also into the realm of the energy transition.
More recent publications63 have moved the STS literature forward by illustrating the constructedness of renewable energy resources, renewable energy sites, landscapes and energy markets.

The STS lens has become useful in shedding critical light on otherwise taken-for-granted truths, such as the assumption that renewable energies are by default ‘sustainable’ as their ‘green’ credentials are often considered part of the ‘good economy’, framed as ‘novel, ethical and good’99.

At the same time, an STS approach can be used to analyse how certain matters of concern come to matter in the design, planning and deployment of renewable energies and what tools, devices and forms of expertise are employed to do so.

We argue that such a socio-technical lens can pry open some of the underlying valuations that come to matter in the governance of the energy transition and in the design of wind turbines and wind farms, providing insights into the often-hidden power and politics of technologies and scientific facts and even of energy epistemologies and ontologies100.
Thus, this lens can shed critical light on power structures and, by doing so, demonstrate otherwise overlooked reasons for local opposition to renewables.

Returning to the grand challenge of climate change, we promote a new life-cycle approach with the aim to overcome SSH’s almost exclusive focus on the planning and development phases of renewables such as wind farms65,101 and the technical literature’s tendency to focus on design and operation.

With our socio-technical lens, the essential research gaps can be addressed by exploring socio-technical grand challenges also related to the design, planning, development, operational and end-of-life phases of wind energy.

Figure 1 illustrates this interdisciplinary approach to the full life cycle, which we lay out in more detail in the following sections as we address the outstanding research issues we have identified.
This diagram shows the socio-technical research gaps in the full wind power life cycle.
The design stage of wind power is the phase that has received the least attention in the existing SSH literature.

This is surprising given the important connection between how wind energy technology is designed and societal concerns about wind turbines and wind farms. It is often overlooked that design issues fundamentally shape future matters, with technical design challenges likely to have socio-technical implications for the subsequent stages of planning, development, operation and end-of-life phases.
The main research gap here is how to meaningfully engage societal actors in the design of wind turbines.
Wind technology design is by nature socio-technical, involving scripts102 or imagined users and imagined lay publics103, even if societal actors are not actually engaged.
Many societal concerns about wind turbines relate directly to design, with issues such as noise104, wind turbine size, shadow flicker105 and obstruction lights106,107 being prominent.
However, little research has been done on how societal actors could be actively involved in addressing these concerns through design.

There are insights on how to organize public engagement in wind farm design, for example, through value-sensitive design108, but we have not seen such methods being applied to early-stage engagement of the public in design of wind turbines or to how innovation is itself influenced by political context, specific forms of expertise and priorities.
Aside from the design of wind turbines, we also foresee a major research gap concerning the societal aspects of digitalization in wind energy.

A proliferation of digital technologies and tools in the wind energy sector is generally seen as a promise to revolutionize how wind energy is designed, planned and managed10, but so far, there has been little research on how to involve societal actors in designing digital technologies.
For example, digital twins are increasingly developed to improve the efficiency of wind turbine design and management while neglecting to engage the public in design and management decisions65.

Another design-related research gap is the discussion around materials, resources used for producing wind turbines and the related justice, inequality and colonialism issues (for example, extraction of raw materials in the Global South, working conditions and so on)35.
This research gap, along with those above related to the design phase, are all related to justice and equity issues in the broader energy transition.

Ultimately, we argue that the challenge of public engagement in wind energy design is to turn the development of technology into a public issue, moving beyond an instrumental ‘acceptance’ perspective towards one of co-creation98,99,109 and ‘material participation’110, so that societal actors come together with wind energy experts to discuss and co-design wind energy systems of the future.
It also means recognizing that energy technologies are themselves objects of engagement that may foster different forms of participation111.

Although abundant SSH research exists around the planning and development of wind energy, most of this up until now has focused somewhat narrowly on procedural considerations, social acceptance and local perspectives111,112.

It should also be highlighted that wind farm siting and development is driven not only by wind resources, local acceptance and planning legislation but also by engagement of non-local actors, including virtual and collective public (for example, regional networks and interest groups).
An important socio-technical research gap in the planning and development phase is how to learn from increasing numbers of single case studies and findings across specific contexts113.

Along with this reasoning, there is also a need to move beyond the Western-centric perspective of the Global North to shed more light on particular planning and development dynamics in contexts in the Global South112,113.
Important considerations include land ownership, division of land assets, dispossession and colonization.
Further, planning and development research should consider Indigenous knowledge in the Global South and the legacy of global energy history and natural resource colonialism114,115.

Socio-technical analysis can help locate power structures, illuminate the impacts of technologies and expose justice-related issues of planning processes designed in the Global North and in the Global South.
Here factors such as technology lock-in without cultural and societal alignment when deploying renewable energy in vulnerable communities should be considered36.
Finally, another less-studied planning and development-related research gap refers to the distributional issues related to wind energy.

A few studies have mapped the distribution of benefits and burdens from wind energy116,117, but the varied impacts when wind energy is co-located or interacts with other technologies is still needed, including cumulative impacts.

Distributional considerations include challenging the notion of social acceptance and NIMBYism with the concepts of acceptability and active agency around technology impacts, the scope of benefits and burdens considered in wind energy planning and the impacts of tools that help plan development63.

The challenge for the operational phase of wind farms is exploring how people relate to, engage with and experience the presence of wind farms in their everyday lives and landscapes so that wind farm operation and management decisions can be improved.

This includes a need to incorporate a dynamic understanding of residents’ concerns and opinions, which means taking into account their social and historical context and potential changes over time101.
Here we argue that a socio-technical approach also can be valuable.
Although it is commonly understood that people who live in the vicinity of wind turbines gradually adapt to them, this cannot be taken for granted118,119.

While it is clear that community concerns about aspects such as noise pollution could be translated into practical guidelines for noise management strategies in wind farms, little research has explored what kind of tools could facilitate that and how local communities could be actively engaged in such management strategies.

Enhancing this topic is the underexplored area of how digital technologies could be used to engage local communities90 and how this could help to gather more realistic (for example, real-time or prolonged) feedback from them about how they perceive the operation of wind farms. One can think here of using applications or platforms to mediate residents’ involvement in wind farm management or more advanced digital technologies such as digital twins that could integrate different kinds of social and environmental models alongside technical ones to identify areas for improvement based on collectively defined objectives.

The socio-technical research gaps relating to the operational phase are particularly challenging as they require exploring how different concerns about wind farm operation intersect with each other (for example, issues about noise are probably related to concerns about visual pollution104).

Thus, a central outstanding research question in the operational phase is the difficulty of capturing and internalizing the dynamic character of the socio-technical aspects into wind farm operation decisions.

Although limited, most research on the end-of-life of wind turbines cycles (including lifetime extension, repowering, decommissioning and recycling) has been based on techno-economic rationales, striving for an efficient use of wind turbines120.
Only very limited research into the end-of-life phase has been conducted from socio-technical, socio-spatial and planning-related perspectives121,122.

The most prevalent socio-technical research gap of this phase relates to how the largely unexplored interaction between different stakeholders and the temporality of wind energy infrastructures shapes the future expansion and sustainability of wind energy.
During planning and development processes, wind turbines are often portrayed as temporary, easily removable infrastructures.
This creates expectations and uncertainties as to what will happen once they reach the end of their operational lifetime, time-limited consents or expiring support mechanisms121.
Compared with other energy infrastructure, the relatively short operational life cycle of turbines (20–25 years) renders wind energy landscapes dynamic, contingent and transient23.
Changes in regulations and set-back distances do not always render all existing sites to be suitable for renewed wind farm projects.
The temporalities of wind turbines and sites thus become debatable once issues of lifetime extensions, repowering or decommissioning are up for discussion122,123.

Although this brings to life social concerns that were potentially settled (for example, conflicts, ownership structures and benefit schemes), end-of-life decisions are often managed in an opaque, fragmented manner.
This raises questions about the governance arrangements for end-of-life practices and about public engagement and participation in repowering, decommissioning and restoration of sites.
It also opens issues of procedural and restorative justice.

Because previous research has highlighted the significance of people–technology–place dynamics in constituting responses to wind turbines on greenfield sites, end-of-life decisions are also likely to affect different understandings and lived experiences of ageing, fading or re-emerging wind energy landscapes.
There is an evident lack of qualitative research dealing with end-of-life considerations relating to how experiences with existing infrastructures may manifest in new iterations of development.

An emerging market for decommissioning or repowering of wind farms also gives rise to future research avenues, enquiring into the global value and supply chains of second-hand wind turbines, the restoration of abandoned sites and changing ownership models of repowered wind farms and how to deal with the environmental pollution of decommissioned wind turbines.

These themes are important because of the wind sector’s general need to perpetuate the merits of a largely undisputed conception of wind turbines as sustainable infrastructures as they are set to become a more dominant component of advanced energy transitions.

Finally, we argue that the STS-based perspective can draw inspiration from a political ecological approach124, which is able to shed light on ‘normal’ structural politics of the energy transition and its local and global manifestations.

Despite ontological and epistemological discrepancies between STS and political ecology, cross-fertilization between the two could demonstrate how politics ‘with a small p’ (of, for example, devices and their political effects as illustrated with an STS lens) and Politics ‘with a capital P’ may blend together125.
From our description of the existing interdisciplinary research gaps in wind energy, it can be seen that they are neither purely social nor purely technical, but socio-technical.
We have thus proposed progressing beyond these polarized approaches to embrace the life cycle of wind power from a socio-technical perspective.

This holds the prospect of ensuring a more inclusive and co-created energy transition where there is space for synergies among a plurality of perspectives, including lay and expert knowledges, and where the sustainability of wind energy expansion can be critically examined.

Critique, contestations and alternative approaches are necessary to forge a truly sustainable and just renewable energy transition67, one that can also critically examine the underlying politics of wind energy innovation, of the schemes that fund research and the types of expertise that inform these.
In promoting a socio-technical lens as a means to this end, we encourage the following three actions: the development of new modes of inter- and transdisciplinary thinking and methods;
revised research funding and wind power deployment support schemes;
and promotion of innovative educational programmes that can grasp the socio-technical nature of wind power deployment.

Regarding the first action, a more holistic and inter- and even transdisciplinary approach to the full socio-technical life cycle of a wind farm can help to include different kinds of scientific expertise and lay knowledge, contributing to solving concerns at the wind farm level and informing research on challenges of wind energy policy and planning and of the energy transition more broadly.

Such an approach could, for instance, help harness the potential of emerging digital technologies (for example, digital twins, remote sensors and software applications), while also providing a critical and reflexive view as to how the use of such digital technologies in the governance of the energy transition raises justice and inequality issues.

Despite the risk of inequality issues, digital technologies (also increasingly including artificial intelligence) may enable the creation of inter- and transdisciplinary spaces for new governance modes to ensure meaningful public engagement with wind power science and technology.
Second, to enable inter- and transdisciplinary research to become more common, we advocate increased funding for experimentation and for compensating the work and involvement of local communities.

To overcome the extractive character of many research projects and to move beyond the tendency to flatten grand challenges by reverting to traditional science, technology and innovation policy3, communities must be empowered to participate in transformative projects.
Similarly, SSH researchers themselves should also be involved over the entire period of research projects, rather than being delegated a discrete work package at the end.
This requires the forging of new knowledge on how to facilitate such truly inter- or transdisciplinary projects and the reconsideration of evaluation criteria for research and innovation projects.

We call for more support for fundamental, theoretical and conceptual research that points to critical socio-technical grand challenges and opens up alternative ways of designing, planning and managing wind energy technologies and landscapes.
Finally, to transform how wind energy science is enacted, a new generation of reflexive engineers and technically minded social and environmental scientists need to be trained.

Although environmental perspectives are not the topic of this paper, a socio-technical lens would also naturally engage with environmental and ecological perspectives, which cannot be detached from the socio-technical issues outlined.
What we advocate is thus ultimately a socio-environmental-technical perspective.
Rethinking education in the context of the identified socio-technical research gaps highlights the necessity of exposing students to these in an integrated manner during their training.

Reforming education will require generating new collaborative capacities, experiments, methodological skills and knowledge of different disciplines to allow for a more holistic understanding of complex issues, the wider context and implications of wind energy.

With this outlook, we hope to challenge STI decisionmakers to re-think the response to the grand challenges discourse to move towards a more interdisciplinary research agenda that can help tackle the tendency to address complex challenges with monodisciplinary solutions.

While promoting an interdisciplinary research agenda, we do not intend to downplay or ignore the continued need for targeted research to make new scientific insights to implement the energy transition in the light of the grand challenge of climate change.

We also fully acknowledge there can be both institutional and disciplinary barriers to interdisciplinarity126,127, and there is often a delicate trade-off to be made between technical and social perspectives.
Here we refer to the need to develop interdisciplinary methods when scaling up the deployment of renewable energy.
These methods will often involve longer engagement processes, and these will need to be integrated in engineering practices through co-design and co-operation.

This may well incur a cost, perhaps in terms of pace, but also in terms of equity when mutually agreeable compromises cannot be achieved and when parallel processes of innovation and assessment of the distribution of costs are necessary.

These challenges deserve exploration on their own terms, but we maintain that the pressing socio-technical research gaps we have outlined are about to constitute grand challenges on their own if not dealt with in a timely fashion.
They will demand that new actors join policy arenas and public debates to ensure their transformative effect.
We propose that wind power constitutes a good site for such exploration of what it might mean for the realization of the energy transition as we face the grand challenge of global climate change.

Renewable energy technologies need more.title: Innovation, Investment, and Inclusion: Accelerating the Energy ...
content: Innovation, Investment, and Inclusion: Accelerating the Energy ...
The White House 1600 Pennsylvania Ave NW Washington, DC 20500 “When I think of climate change, I think about jobs.
Good-paying, union jobs that put Americans to work, make our air cleaner, and rebuild America’s crumbling infrastructure.
” —President Joe Biden1 On July 20, 1969, Neil Armstrong became the first person to walk on the Moon.
This achievement was the result of a decade of work by hundreds of thousands of U.
S.
workers across a wide array of scientific and technical fields (Ghosh 2021).
The moonshot was an all-of- government approach to innovation that has paid off for decades.

New ideas developed in the wake of that moonwalk—from telecommunications to the Internet to silicon chips—have led to commercial advances and vital industries, which have produced strong economic growth and well-paying, middle-class, often union jobs.
Combating climate change is the 21st-century moonshot, though on a much grander scale.
Extreme weather and climate events—like storms, floods, and wildfires—have already caused about $120 billion a year in damages to the United States over the past five years (NCEI 2021).

These costs are on course to accelerate as higher temperatures, rising sea levels, and extreme weather increasingly damage infrastructure and coastal property, alter crop yields, and reduce labor productivity.
If left unaddressed, these damages will drag down economic productivity and growth in the United States.
At the same time, tackling them and building resilience against them can provide a foundation for strong, stable, and shared economic growth.
A critical challenge is to find ways of producing increasingly cheap, reliable, and clean energy.
These innovations will define many of the most important industries for decades to come, and with them, the jobs of the future.
There has been remarkable progress along these lines: The fastest-growing power generation technologies are solar and wind (EIA 2021;
IEA 2020a), which have seen cost reductions of 70 to 90 percent over the past decade (NAS 2021, 3).
Progress on clean energy technologies has led to further deployments, and the knowledge gained from these deployments has then led to further cost reductions.
Yet technologies have neither been developed nor implemented on the scale needed to stabilize global temperatures and avoid the worsening threats of climate change.
Some countries are making bold attempts to foster these new technologies, while also increasing their own economic competitiveness.

The European Union, the United Kingdom, and Canada have all recently announced new industrial policy strategies to prepare their domestic industries and workers for the energy transition, while China’s strong support of its domestic industries has made it the global leader in clean energy manufacturing.

We can already see how the United States is falling behind in developing innovations that will define this century: Innovation in new energy technologies could support both economic growth and the creation of well-paying jobs.
Yet, unlike most of its major trading partners, the U.
S.
government has not adopted a robust strategy to encourage the innovation and deployment of clean energy or to support U.
S.
workers and communities through the energy transition.

Absent such a strategy, workers could be hit by the dual negative effects of declining jobs in high-carbon industries alongside too few new domestic jobs in the emerging carbon-free industries of the future.
Markets alone will not accelerate the energy transition at a sufficient pace or scale to address the climate crisis.
The Federal Government has a critical role to play to catalyze the private sector into actions to ensure that the U.
S.
economy is competitive with the rest of the world (Block and Keller 2011;
Mazzucato 2013;
Rodrik 2004).

The goal should be to identify and intervene in the strategic areas where government interventions—often in partnership with the private sector— can help build a fairer, more productive, and cleaner economy.

Without an intentional focus on equity, the benefits and costs of the energy transition will not be fairly distributed among Americans at different income levels, geographic regions, races, and occupations (Carley and Konisky 2020).

Recent government policy has failed to sufficiently protect lower-income groups from bearing a disproportionate share of previous major transitions, such as globalization (Autor, Dorn, and Hanson 2016).
We must do better in managing the transition to clean energy.
3 This report is divided into three sections.
The first section lays out the innovation challenge, and how the United States is falling behind and what the implications are for investment and jobs.

The second section identifies the barriers that inhibit private actors alone from sufficiently investing in clean energy innovation, and thus why Federal policy and public-private partnerships are crucial.
And the third section proposes policy responses to foster clean energy innovation and create good jobs.

Specifically, the Federal Government should accelerate energy innovation through policies that: This agenda is not a comprehensive response to the climate and inequality-based threats, but together, they are a significant down payment on responding to each.
The science is clear: climate change poses a dire threat to humanity.
Fortunately, creating the technologies that reduce climate risks presents a huge economic opportunity.
The question is whether the United States will lead in developing and producing innovative technologies to address climate change, or accept that others will dominate this field.
If it chooses the latter, it will fail to support the entry of U.
S.
companies and workers into a growing market.
The United States’ ingenuity put a person on the Moon.
It must now lead in preserving a livable planet.
Although the world is on the cusp of transformational technological breakthroughs in a variety of energy-related areas, neither the innovation nor deployment of clean energy is happening fast enough.
Carbon dioxide concentrations in the atmosphere are far higher than they have been for at least hundreds of thousands of years and continue to grow.
Climate risks involve stresses to interconnected systems—health, energy, water, food, ecosystems—with cascading effects;
see figure 1.
Lower-income and marginalized populations will be disproportionately harmed because they lack the resources to adequately prepare or cope with extreme weather events (USGCRP 2018).
In order to address the causes and consequences of climate change, there is a need for technologies that reduce carbon emissions and are deployed at scale.
While both public and private actors have begun to implement strategies around the globe that reduce emissions, these efforts have been too slow and too small.

Figure 2 shows that annual global carbon dioxide emissions are on pace to stay roughly at their current level through 2040, whereas the United States and all other major countries agreed to achieve net zero emissions at the global level in the second half this century to avoid ever-worsening climate threats (UNFCCC 2015, 4).
The lack of widespread adoption of clean energy technologies to reduce carbon emissions has significant and growing economic costs.

While estimates of the damages caused by ever- worsening climate change are highly speculative, a recent meta-analysis of the relationship between global temperatures and climate damages shows that, at the global level, damage could rise to roughly 7 to 10 percent of GDP at 3 degrees of warming Celsius—equal to 5.
4 degrees Fahrenheit (Howard and Sterner 2017)—which could occur later this century in the absence of strong policy interventions.
Focusing specifically on the U.
S.
economy, Kahn and others (2019) estimate the costs of economic damages using an econometric approach that links changes in climate from historical norms to changes in real output per capita.
They find that increases in temperatures lead to losses in U.
S.
GDP per capita of between 0.
3 and 5.
4 percent by 2050 across a wide range of scenarios.
4 One specific cost is in future worker productivity.
The same sources that emit greenhouse gases are responsible for emissions of particulate matter and other local air pollutants that cause sickness and death.
Air pollution keeps U.
S.
workers from their jobs and reduces their productivity when they can work (Currie and Walker 2019;
Zivin and Neidell 2012), especially lower-income groups and communities of color (Currie and Walker 2019).

The flipside to these costs is that there are profitable opportunities for firms that can find commercially viable ways to address them by supplying both domestic and foreign consumers, as well as for the U.
S.
workers who gain those jobs.

The fastest-growing power generation technologies are solar and wind (EIA 2021), and some estimate that annual global deployments of solar could increase by nearly 50 percent (under stated policies) to almost 200 percent (with further policy ambition), according to the International Energy Agency (IEA 2020e, 35).

Projections from Bloomberg New Energy Finance show that annual sales of internal combustion vehicles are now permanently declining, and the electric vehicle share of new global car sales is expected to rise from 2 percent today to nearly 30 percent by 2030 (BNEF 2020a, 2021b).
Indeed, the economic opportunities are substantial because the challenge is so large.

Notably, analysis from the International Energy Agency shows that a successful global emissions pathway could require one-third to one-half of the emissions reductions over the next half century to come from technologies that are not yet commercially viable (IEA 2020b).

The global nature of climate change, combined with the economic gains for those who can first come up with solutions that are brought to market at scale, underscores the economic opportunities of clean energy innovation.
There are many reasons why the United States should take an active role in the research and deployment of new energy technologies.
U.
S.
companies have a century-long track record of becoming global leaders in industries ranging from computers to pharmaceuticals to telecommunications, among many others.
U.
S.
workers are relatively well-trained to meet the labor demands of a new set of industries (NAS 2021, 3).
U.
S.
firms are well positioned to make these investments, given relatively strong cash reserves and relatively low interest rates.
Indeed, some U.
S.
firms are taking steps toward carbon-free energy.
Global companies with a combined revenue of over $11 trillion—more than half of U.
S.
GDP—have committed to pursuing net-zero emissions, with the majority aiming for 2050 or earlier (UN Climate 2020).
Many of the most valuable U.
S.
companies—such as Google, Apple, Amazon, Facebook, and Microsoft—have strengthened their climate and clean energy commitments in recent years (Hook and Lee 2021).
Perhaps the most telling sign of momentum toward a clean energy economy is coming from high-emitting sectors.

For example, some of the nation’s largest electric utilities—including Duke Energy, Xcel Energy, and Southern Company—have announced goals to achieve net zero emissions by 2050, and General Motors says it will eliminate gasoline-powered, light-duty vehicles by 2035 (St.
John 2020;
Boudette and Davenport 2021).
Of course, pledges of future action should be taken with an appropriate grain of salt, but the increased climate-related commitments and actions from corporations in recent years is unmistakable.
Yet the scale and scope of U.
S.
investments in the necessary innovation, commercialization, and infrastructure are insufficient, in terms of both public and private action.

In a recent report, the World Economic Forum created an index of “energy transition readiness” that evaluated how well countries were positioned for the coming transition based on factors including the level of political commitment, investment climate, access to capital, consumer engagement, development and adoption of new technologies, and stability of the political environment.

The United States is tied for 28th, out of 115 countries studied, indicating the failure to invest in the transition to low- carbon energy (the top-scoring countries are shown in figure 3) (WEF 2020, 13).
As U.
S.
investments in climate innovation have stagnated, other countries have taken the lead.

For example, the market share of Chinese companies is nearly 60 percent for the manufacturing of wind turbines, nearly 80 percent for solar module cells, and over 80 percent for battery cells, which are used in electric vehicles (see figure 4).
Similarly, the majority of the chips used in light-emitting diodes (LEDs)—a technology that relies on U.
S.
-funded innovations—are now produced in China (CEMAC 2021).

This United States’ lack of investment in R&D is especially worrisome given the advantages that flow to those who can first capture a particular market, and the rich body of evidence for a close empirical link between R&D spending and different measures of innovation, including patents and venture capital investments (Azoulay et al.
Howell 2017).
This lost opportunity for American leadership not only means a missed chance to satisfy the energy needs of tomorrow;
it could also mean growing dependence upon more intrepid countries.
Indeed, in ceding ground to economic competitors, the United States may be putting the Nation at risk, to the extent that these sectors are critical for national security or resilience.
The opportunity remains, however, for the United States to play a larger role in accelerating the clean energy and supporting industries that can provide good jobs for U.
S.
workers.
Innovation in clean energy is important for the U.
S.
economy as well as the planet.
Already, the private sector in the United States is taking steps to advance low-carbon technologies.
However, as the first section explained, clean energy technologies have not yet emerged at the pace and scale needed to address the risks of climate change, nor to ensure that U.
S.
firms are leading the way.
The question is, why not?
Given the economic, geopolitical, equity, and climate imperatives to accelerate the development and deployment of clean energy technologies, what is the appropriate role for government?

The answer is twofold: there are a series of barriers that discourage the private sector from developing new energy technologies, and the United States has not implemented a national strategy to address these hurdles and instead nurture this transformation.

In economics, it is well known that there are situations when private actors cannot and do not engage in economically and socially meaningful activities because market prices do not accurately reflect the social costs and benefits.
Economists call these market failures.
One special case is when the provision of goods is open and available to benefit a range of individuals, then an individual firm cannot properly recoup its investment.
These are called public goods—think of clean air, where one person’s use would not prohibit someone else from using it.

Similar to investments in technological progress, the private sector will underinvest in infrastructure because the benefits spill over to people who cannot easily be charged for using the infrastructure, and this undermines the returns that flow directly back to the investor.

In the case of emerging energy technologies, there are at least six theoretical reasons why private actors alone are not taking action at sufficient scale or speed: (1) private actors underinvest in basic research that drives economy-wide innovation;
(2) markets underprice the growing side effects and cost of climate change, such as the fires, floods, and droughts that continued emissions have brought and will continue to bring;
(3) markets fail to ensure the adoption of low- cost energy-saving opportunities;
(4) private actors alone do not supply sufficient energy infrastructure—clean or otherwise—due to their inability to coordinate sectors and workers on a large scale;
(5) markets fail to account for industry-level spillovers and agglomeration;
and (6) markets fail to support the kinds of high-quality jobs for domestic workers that are included in the industrial strategies of many other nations.

In practice, these barriers play out within the context of often-heated political debates over questions of distribution—who gains and who loses as the economy transforms. Today, these debates are being heightened by high economic inequality and the fact that some places have greatly benefited from the most recent economic changes, such as Silicon Valley, while others have not, such as those hit by the “China Shock” (Autor, Dorn, and Hanson 2016).
This section lays out each of the six barriers in turn.

Private Actors Underinvest in Basic Research An individual firm will continue to make investments in research and development as long as it believes the expected (marginal) benefits will outweigh the expected (marginal) costs.
However, when a firm spends resources on the basic research that underlies technological progress, it also creates benefits for others, through knowledge spillovers.
The production and consumption of new technologies also create information that benefits others, through learning-by-doing and learning-by-using.
Because these spillovers do not directly benefit the firm, the firm does not count them as benefits;
from the perspective of society, firms are underinvesting in technological progress.

This is underscored by the uncertain and long-term nature of investments in many cutting-edge clean energy technologies, which do not line up well with the private sector’s desire for more certain and near-term profits.
U.
S.

companies, particularly publicly traded ones, are evaluated based on their quarterly earnings and short-term outlooks, which discourages them from taking a long-term perspective (Karlsson and Palladino 2018).

On account of spillover benefits, the social returns of investments in R&D—that is, not only the total economic returns to the initial firm but also the returns that accrue to other firms and the public—are almost always substantially greater than the private returns to the investing firm (Hall, Mairesse, and Mohnen 2010).
One study found that the social return to R&D is 58 percent, four times the private return of 14 percent (Lucking, Bloom, and Van Reenen 2019).

A National Academies study reviewed over two decades of experience with the Department of Energy’s research, development, and demonstration programs in energy efficiency and found that the total net realized economic benefits were about $46 billion, over four times as large as the government investment of about $11 billion (all valued in 2020 dollars) (NRC 2001).
5 Individual private actors are “free-riders” on these large spillovers.

The investments are costly, but because the benefits are diffuse, investments in public R&D are needed to ensure that there is adequate support for solving society’s most important problems. Not only does public investment have high direct returns;
there is also evidence that it can stimulate additional private investment (Pereira 2001).

An example of public investment that helped to establish profitable new industries was the Internet, which resulted from a series of investments by the Department of Defense (Mowery and Simcoe 2002) (see box 1).

The solar industry remains mostly nonunion, and wages are often relatively low.

Loomis 2018).

One recent study concludes that “high road” labor practices can coexist with the rapid expansion of the domestic solar and wind energy markets: a 20 percent increase in domestic labor costs increases installed capital costs for wind and solar power by just 2 to 4 percent, and operations and maintenance costs by about 3 to 6 percent (Jenkins and Mayfield 2021).
